abstract: “The Hobbit” will be in 3-D. That is a measure of how much the movie world has changed in the last year or so. Tolkien book, then to be directed by Guillermo del Toro, insisted that 2-D screen technology was just right for a pair of movies that were viewed as being a little more intimate than their sweeping precursors, in the “Lord of the Rings” trilogy.
snippet: “The Hobbit” will be in 3-D. That is a measure of how much the movie world has changed in the last year or so. In the dimly remembered recesses of, oh, 2009, people involved with the two-movie version of the J. R. R. Tolkien book, then to be direc...
lead_paragraph: So “The Hobbit” will be in 3-D. That is a measure of how much the movie world has changed in the last year or so. In the dimly remembered recesses of, oh, 2009, people involved with the two-movie version of the J. R. R. Tolkien book, then to be directed by Guillermo del Toro, insisted that 2-D screen technology was just right for a pair of movies that were viewed as being a little more intimate than their sweeping precursors in the “Lord of the Rings” trilogy. Then came “Avatar,” “Alice in Wonderland,” and even the much-maligned “Clash of the Titans” — one film after another proving that viewers would pay a premium for 3-D, as long as the underlying movie wasn’t an utter bust.

headline.main: Big Hairy Feet, Now in 3-D?

lead_paragraph: A nonprofit group that complained that Pepsi had allowed organizations with political agendas to participate in its online giving contest, Pepsi Refresh, won one of the two $250,000 prizes. The group, Arms Wide Open Childhood Cancer Foundation, raises money for alternative therapies and treatments for children with neuroblastoma. The group contended that 16 contestant-groups that were members of the Progressive Slate were political groups tied to the Democratic party and thus violated contest rules. Pepsi disagreed, saying the groups were not advocating for a particular candidate or issue. Eight of those groups won $50,000 prizes.

abstract: As managers try to ensure their companies’ survival, many are also refusing to take creative risks. But such a fortress mentality makes the unemployment problem only worse.
snippet: As managers try to ensure their companies’ survival, many are also refusing to take creative risks. But such a fortress mentality makes the unemployment problem only worse.
lead_paragraph: CORPORATE managers struggling to preserve their companies and protect their core employees have inadvertently contributed to a vicious cycle of rising unemployment and plummeting national morale. If we are to break out of this downward spiral, we first need to understand the problem, then deal with it on a huge scale.

headline.main: The Survival of the Safest
headline.print_headline: The Survival Of the Safest

abstract: Kate Logan, C.E.O. of a bankruptcy administration firm, learned management skills and patience as the oldest girl in a family of 10 children.
snippet: Kate Logan, C.E.O. of a bankruptcy administration firm, learned management skills and patience as the oldest girl in a family of 10 children.
lead_paragraph: I’M one of 10 children in my family. My mother, a nurse, was always busy around the house or taking care of a new baby. As the second-oldest child and the oldest girl, I became a surrogate parent to many of my siblings.

headline.main: Lessons in a Large Family
headline.print_headline: Lessons in a Large Family

abstract: After years in corporate work, Maria Sazon decided to take a job at the nonprofit National Alliance for Public Charter Schools in Washington.
snippet: After years in corporate work, Maria Sazon decided to take a job at the nonprofit National Alliance for Public Charter Schools in Washington.
lead_paragraph: IN May, I moved from a corporate job to nonprofit work. I had been a vice president at a large financial services firm in New York, analyzing risks and recommending investments in tax-exempt portfolios. I specialized in bonds issued by state and local governments; public and private schools, colleges and universities; and other nonprofit organizations. Before that, I was a credit analyst at a bond insurance company.

headline.main: Measuring Success by Mission, Not Profit

abstract: A new book by Nicholas Phillipson traces the intellectual development of Adam Smith, founder of modern economics.
snippet: A new book by Nicholas Phillipson traces the intellectual development of Adam Smith, founder of modern economics.
lead_paragraph: MEASURED by fame and lasting influence, there is no other book on economics that comes close to “The Wealth of Nations” by Adam Smith. Many aspects of this book, first published in 1776, have become cornerstones of neoclassical economics: the organizing power of self-interest, the “invisible hand” of free markets and the crucial role of the division of labor are just three examples.

headline.main: The Wealth of an Intellect
headline.print_headline: The Wealth of an Intellect

abstract: In a study, students were asked to think about fruit salad and a cheesecake and then estimate the calories in a cheeseburger.
snippet: In a study, students were asked to think about fruit salad and a cheesecake and then estimate the calories in a cheeseburger.
lead_paragraph: When people make numerical estimates, they are notoriously subject to the distorting influence of “anchors”: numbers previously observed that linger in the mind and drag up or down the later estimate. A new study describes a related but opposite effect: when the anchor is in a very different category, it can drive the target estimate away, rather than pulling it closer.

headline.main: Sizing Up a Cheeseburger’s Caloric Heft
headline.print_headline: Sizing Up a Cheeseburger’s Caloric Heft

lead_paragraph: The editors of Maclean’s, the venerable weekly Canadian magazine, have made provocative covers something of a specialty. But none of their earlier efforts produced quite the same response as an image of Bonhomme Carnaval, the snowman mascot of Quebec’s winter festival, jauntily carrying a briefcase overflowing with cash. The bold cover headline on the issue of Oct. 4 was no more subtle: “Quebec: The Most Corrupt Province.”

abstract: Checking in on city businesses struggling to survive.
snippet: Checking in on city businesses struggling to survive.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a year after the Federal Reserve Bank of New York deemed the recession over, many small-business owners are still waiting for real signs of recovery. In this video, part of a series of articles and videos that have followed several small businesses in New York City since 2008, one gets a glimpse of how unevenly the economic rebound is playing out across the city and various industries. A bicycle manufacturer in Queens has adapted to changing markets and come out a leaner, more diversified company. Meanwhile, a butcher in the Bronx recently closed shop because of outstanding debt.

headline.main: Video Series: Small Business and the Recession

abstract: And do stay-at-home moms hurt the cause?
snippet: And do stay-at-home moms hurt the cause?
lead_paragraph: For American women, the days of overt “Mad Men”-style discrimination are largely gone. Women outnumber men at universities, have career options beyond the secretarial pool, and are (slowly) narrowing the pay gap with their male peers. So why has this half of the population failed to reach critical mass in leadership roles across industries? She Owns It explored the topic here, and author Gloria Feldt answers the question in her new book, No Excuses: 9 Ways Women Can Change the Way We Think About Power and Leadership. Ms. Feldt, the former president and chief executive of Planned Parenthood, recently spoke with me about why women’s progress is stalled, her hope that a female Steve Jobs will soon emerge and the dangers of being a stay-at-home mom. A condensed version of the conversation follows.

headline.main: Where Is the Female Steve Jobs?

The company reported its first annual profit in four years after the markets closed on Thursday. Micron said net income was 32 cents a share, after a loss of $100 million, or 12 cents, a year earlier. The company said sales in the period, which ended Sept. 2, almost doubled to $2.49 billion. Stock in Micron, which is based in Boise, Idaho, rose 48 cents, to $7.59 a share.

abstract: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners.

lead_paragraph: MAYBE I SHOULD HIRE SOMEONE. Intuit’s small-business employment index for September shows slowing job growth, reporting that “for small businesses with fewer than 20 employees, only 27,000 new jobs were created.” Compensation also declined. “It’s a disappointing number, but it’s not unexpected,” Joel Prakken, chairman of Macroeconomic Advisors, told CNBC. “G.D.P. growth has slowed to below the growth rate of productivity, and it’s inevitable that you’d have this deceleration in jobs.” The overall unemployment rate stayed close to 10 percent. Even the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004 made little impact according to research by Mitchell Petersen, a professor of finance at the Kellogg School of Management. Anyone out there hiring?

headline.main: This Week in Small Business: Bankruptcies, Waivers and iPads

lead_paragraph: Hot money (money in pursuit of short-term gains) is the bugbear of policy makers in many developing economies. Ask Brazil or, indeed, Thailand, which just imposed a 15 percent withholding tax on interest and capital gains earned by foreign investors on Thai bonds. One worry is that booming currencies will become uncompetitive; another is that easy-come, easy-go money will make economies vulnerable to booms and busts.

abstract: More than food or fire or grapes, people are the vital elements of any restaurant. They are also exhausting.
snippet: More than food or fire or grapes, people are the vital elements of any restaurant. They are also exhausting.
lead_paragraph: Call me naïve. Some years ago — never mind how long precisely — having no literary project on the boards, I thought I would open a small fish joint in this watery end of the world. Little did I imagine the sheer volume of human beings with whom I would come into contact on a daily, no, hourly basis. All manner of humans: professional, half-formed and holy humans; newbies and wannabes; multilingual, minimally trained, overqualified, fried, rehabbing, should-be-rehabbing humans; ambitious people, passionate people and degenerate people. They surround you like the ocean. You could drown in them. They keep you afloat. They are exhausting.

headline.main: And Then There’s Mrs. B

abstract: Talking female entrepreneurship at “Davos for women.”
snippet: Talking female entrepreneurship at “Davos for women.”
lead_paragraph: This week I travel to Deauville, France, to attend the sixth Women’s Forum for the Economy and Society, an annual meeting that brings together influential women — and men — from around the world. Described as “Davos for Women,” the forum was founded by French entrepreneur Aude de Thuin, who saw a need to give voice to the other half of the population after she failed to receive an invitation to the predominantly male gathering in the Swiss Alps. The 2010 forum will focus on change in politics, the economy, the environment, global health, and the steps necessary to enable progress in all by facilitating full participation by women.

headline.main: Reporting From the Women’s Forum

lead_paragraph: It’s great to get the comments to my introductory post. Like pretty much all working human beings — and unlike our computers and gadgets, unless there’s a new iPhone app I’ve missed — I appreciate appreciation, so thanks much for the welcoming notes. I do, however, try to pay special attention to criticisms, concerns and requests, in the hopes that they can lead me to do at least an incrementally better job. snippet: Molecular Insight Pharmaceuticals, a biotechnology development company, reported positive results from a clinical trial of a treatment that detects prostate cancer, setting off a 65 percent gain in its share price.
lead_paragraph: Molecular Insight Pharmaceuticals, a biotechnology development company, reported positive results from a clinical trial of a treatment that detects prostate cancer, setting off a 65 percent gain in its share price. The company released the results of the early stage trial of the treatment, called Trofex, after the market closed Thursday. On Friday, shares of Molecular Insight, which is based in Cambridge, Mass., rose 50 cents, to $1.27. The news came a week after Nasdaq told Molecular Insight that it was in danger of being delisted because the company’s stock had remained below $1 a share for 30 consecutive business days. Also on Friday, the company said it had reached an agreement to extend a waiver with bondholders to allow debt restructuring negotiations to continue until next Friday.

headline.main: Biotech Company Gains on Prostate Cancer Trial
headline.print_headline: Biotech Company Gains On Prostate Cancer Trial

abstract: Should the plant hire new employees? Should it buy new equipment? It’s tough to pull the trigger right now.

lead_paragraph: I started writing for this blog some 10 months ago — a time when just about everyone, including me, was trying to sort out what was going on in the economy. In the months since then, I’ve shared many stories with you about how open-book management has helped propel SRC Holdings through at least three recessions and has set us up to take advantage of the recovery. That’s also why I’ve written several times about our manufacturing facility in Lexington, Ky. — the plant we purchased not long before I started this blog. I chose to share the stories from Lexington because I thought it would help illustrate what happens when a traditionally run company opens its books.

headline.main: Coping With Economic Uncertainty

lead_paragraph: A camera-store salesman recently steered me away from the compact, ultrahigh-tech camera I thought I wanted. Smaller is fine, he told me, but only if it fits in your pocket — any bigger will end up hanging from your shoulder anyway, so what’s the advantage? And don’t buy based on fancy features, he added; the differences between comparable models rarely result in better pictures for amateurs. The one feature you’ll really appreciate, he said, is how the camera feels in your hand.

abstract: The tussle between producers of two films based on “The Hobbit” and a New Zealand union is still going on, despite a move on Wednesday by the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists to lift a ban that had kept members from working on the films.
snippet: The tussle between producers of two films based on “The Hobbit” and a New Zealand union is still going on, despite a move on Wednesday by the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists to lift a ban that had ke...
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES—The tussle between producers of two planned films based on “The Hobbit” and a New Zealand union is still going on, despite a move on Wednesday by the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists to lift a ban that had kept members from working on the films. As of Thursday morning, according to a person briefed on the matter, Warner’s New Line unit, which is supervising the production for Warner Brothers and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, was still considering a move to another country, in part because, in the studios’ view, the New Zealand actors, despite having withdrawn their call for an international union boycott, are continuing to insist that the “Hobbit” producers conduct discussions that would run afoul of New Zealand law. A team of Warner executives is expected to be in New Zealand by Tuesday, both to assess the situation and to consider plans for production elsewhere.

headline.main: New Zealand Still in ‘Hobbit’ Picture, for Now

abstract: It’s easy to expose your company to hackers with poor password practices — but there is an equally easy solution.
snippet: It’s easy to expose your company to hackers with poor password practices — but there is an equally easy solution.
lead_paragraph: Back in the 1990s fellow science and technology journalist Charles Mann and I wrote a book uncovering the true story of how a lone, young, cognitively impaired hacker with relatively few computer skills managed to perpetrate what was then the most extensive and scariest series of computer break-ins ever — government weapons labs, dam control systems and ATM networks were among the hundreds of networks compromised. At the end of the book, we predicted that no matter how much effort was poured into making the Internet safer, hackers would always be able to have a field day, partly for technical reasons but also because companies and individuals would never get it together to take simple precautions critical to safe computing.

headline.main: How a Pas5woRd Can Sink Your Company

abstract: The Deal Professor examines a shareholder lawsuit against Barnes & Noble’s board and considers the Delaware Chancery Court’s murky doctrine for determining independent directors.
snippet: The Deal Professor examines a shareholder lawsuit against Barnes & Noble’s board and considers the Delaware Chancery Court’s murky doctrine for determining independent directors.
lead_paragraph: Truly independent directors can be hard to spot. The reason is that the conflicts that create doubt as to a director’s independence can be so subtle and hidden. It is easy to know that the spouse of the chief executive is not independent, but what about a best friend from high school? When do relationships, social or otherwise, arise to the level that a conflict is created and director independence is questionable?

headline.main: How Independent Are Barnes & Noble Directors?

lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, the Harvard economist N. Gregory Mankiw wrote a Times column about how higher taxes would reduce his incentives to work. The column incited heated debates from all over the blogosphere, as well as on The Colbert Report.

abstract: The United States, Europe and industry should work together so no nation can disrupt supplies of crucial raw materials, officials said.
snippet: The United States, Europe and industry should work together so no nation can disrupt supplies of crucial raw materials, officials said.

headline.print_headline: U.S. and Europe Urged to Join Forces on Rare Earth Metals

abstract: Regulators say that GlaxoSmithKline, the British drug giant, knowingly sold tainted baby ointment and an ineffective antidepressant.
snippet: Regulators say that GlaxoSmithKline, the British drug giant, knowingly sold tainted baby ointment and an ineffective antidepressant.
lead_paragraph: GlaxoSmithKline, the British drug giant, has agreed to pay $750 million to settle criminal and civil complaints that the company for years knowingly sold contaminated baby ointment and an ineffective antidepressant  the latest in a growing number of whistle-blower lawsuits that drug makers have settled with multimillion-dollar fines.

headline.main: Glaxo to Pay $750 Million for Sale of Bad Products

abstract: Judging the White House and Congress, on the short-term and the long-term.

lead_paragraph: For someone judging the Obama administration’s first two years of policy making, the biggest black mark would be the current state of the economy. The administration — along with the Federal Reserve — succeeded in breaking the back of a huge financial crisis. But the administration — and, again, the Fed — also turned too timid this year. That timidity seems all but certain to cost the Democrats next week.

lead_paragraph: New data released by the University of New Hampshire’s Center for Venture Research found that angel investors put much less money into start-up deals during the first half of 2010 than they did in 2009, a direct refutation of the widely held notion in Silicon Valley that seed valuations had been rising.

headline.main: Has the Seed Investment Bubble Burst?

abstract: Are the companies that refuse to accept American Express really saving money?
snippet: Are the companies that refuse to accept American Express really saving money?
lead_paragraph: One of the keys to making money is to keep your costs down. Sometimes, in the effort to save money, a company can be the victim of unintended consequences. You “save” some money by putting off machine maintenance, and a machine breaks down and stops production. You “save” some money by changing insurance companies, and you find out after you make a claim why the new company is cheaper. You “save” money by not doing safety training in your factory, and someone gets hurt doing something the wrong way.

headline.main: Expensive Ways to Save Money

So when some guy was willing to trash Christine O’Donnell, the Republican candidate for United States Senate in Delaware, for the small money Gawker paid for the scoop, it was just one more step down the road to clickable perdition. Except even as she was being fed into the digital wood chipper, various other parties on the Web began to step back and wonder why a pretty average night between seemingly normal people was being pathologized.

headline.main: By Any Means Necessary: Gawker and the O’Donnell Post

abstract: Matt Tolmach, who had been jointly overseeing Columbia Pictures in a co-presidency with his fellow executive Doug Belgrad, is leaving the executive team to become a producer, with a choice assignment as one of the producers of the next “Spider-Man” film.
snippet: Matt Tolmach, who had been jointly overseeing Columbia Pictures in a co-presidency with his fellow executive Doug Belgrad, is leaving the executive team to become a producer, with a choice assignment as one of the producers of the next “Spider-Man...
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES—There’s been some moving and shaking among the movers and shakers at Columbia Pictures. Matt Tolmach, who had been jointly overseeing Columbia Pictures in a co-presidency with his fellow executive Doug Belgrad, is leaving the executive team for a choice assignment as one of the producers of the next “Spider-Man” film. Mr. Belgrad becomes Columbia’s sole president, while Hannah Minghella was named production president of Columbia. Ms. Minghella was previously the production president of Sony Pictures Animation. Michael Lynton remains the chairman and chief executive of Sony Pictures Entertainment, which includes Columbia, and Amy Pascal remains the co-chairwoman of Sony Pictures. “I couldn’t be happier for or prouder of Matt, Doug and Hannah,” Ms. Pascal said in a statement on Friday.

headline.main: A Shifting at the Top of Columbia Pictures

abstract: Avanir Pharmaceuticals won approval for a drug that curbs bouts of uncontrolled laughing or crying in patients with neurological disorders, regulators said
snippet: Avanir Pharmaceuticals won approval for a drug that curbs bouts of uncontrolled laughing or crying in patients with neurological disorders, regulators said
lead_paragraph: Avanir Pharmaceuticals won approval for a drug that curbs bouts of uncontrolled laughing or crying in patients with neurological disorders, regulators said. The medicine, Nuedexta, is the first approved to treat patients with multiple sclerosis or Lou Gehrig’s disease who develop symptoms known as pseudobulbar affect that causes loss of emotional control, the Food and Drug Administration said. Avanir, which has no other products on the market, said it planned to begin selling the drug in the first three months of 2011. Shares of Avanir, which is based in Aliso Viejo, Calif., more than doubled in after hours trading to $5.17.

headline.main: Drug For Neurological Disorders Cleared By F.D.A.
